headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Jessica and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Laura Murphy, Vice President of Corporate Fin
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Jessica and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Laura Murphy, Vice President of Corporate Finance, you may begin.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's quarterly conference call. Joining me on today's call will be Frank ten Brink, CFO; Rich Kogler, COO; and Mark Miller, Chairman and CEO. I will now read the safe harbor statement. Statements by Stericycle in this conference call th
componenttext: Welcome to Stericycle's quarterly conference call. Joining me on today's call will be Frank ten Brink, CFO; Rich Kogler, COO; and Mark Miller, Chairman and CEO. I will now read the safe harbor statement. Statements by Stericycle in this conference call that are not strictly historical are forward-looking. Forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks and should be viewed with caution. Factors described in the company's Form 10-K, 10-Qs, as well as its other filings with the SEC could affect the company's actual results and could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from expected results. The company makes no commitment to disclose any revisions to forward-looking statements or any facts, events or circumstances after the statements made thereupon forward-looking statements. I will now turn it over to Frank.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows. Revenues were $393.5 million, up 25.5% from $313.5 million in the fourth quarter of '09. Domestic revenues were $292.6 million. Domestic regulated waste and compliance services revenues
componenttext: Thank you, Laura. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows. Revenues were $393.5 million, up 25.5% from $313.5 million in the fourth quarter of '09. Domestic revenues were $292.6 million. Domestic regulated waste and compliance services revenues were $250 million and the returns and recall revenues were $42.6 million. The international revenues were $100.9 million, including an unfavorable exchange impact of $1 million. Domestic internal growth, excluding returns management, was up approximately 8%, consisting of Small Quantity, up 9% and Large Quantity, up 6%. International internal growth, adjusted for exchange, was up approximately 8%. Acquisitions less than 12 months old contributed $32.5 million to the growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $182.5 million or 46.4% of revenues and SG&A expense was $75.7 million or 19.2% of revenues. Net interest expense was $10.7 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $50 million or $0.50 per share on an as-reported basis and $0.69 adjusted for after-tax transaction expenses related also to other adjustments. At the end of the quarter, our revolver borrowings were approximately $175 million and is floating at LIBOR plus 75 basis points. The unused portion of the revolver debt at the end of the quarter was approximately $491 million. As we mentioned before, in October 15, 2010, we received the $400 million private placement and those proceeds were used to prepay part of the term debt that we have and reduce the revolver. We purchased 709,867 shares of common stock in the open market in the quarter at an amount of $50.7 million. Capital spending was $12.4 million and DSO at the end of the quarter was 51 days. The cash provided from operations was $325.7 million for the year, which includes $23 million of cash received from the fourth quarter from our customers to be used for recalled product reimbursement. Those are my comments. I will now turn it over to Rich.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Frank. At the end of the quarter, we had approximately 485,400 accounts, of which over 472,000 were small and the remainder were large. We continue to see strong growth worldwide, driven by new account acquisition and the adoption of our expanding
componenttext: Thanks, Frank. At the end of the quarter, we had approximately 485,400 accounts, of which over 472,000 were small and the remainder were large. We continue to see strong growth worldwide, driven by new account acquisition and the adoption of our expanding portfolio of service offerings. With our Large Quantity customers, we have multiple service offerings, which add to the value of each account and today, less than 20% of our LQ customers are using our multiple services, leaving more than 80% of our LQ customer base available for growth. Likewise, with our Small Quantity customers, we offer multiple services that increase the value of an account and today, approximately a third of our SQ customers utilize multiple services, leaving 2/3 of our customer base available for growth. In closing, we want to thank each member of our worldwide team for their solid performance leading to a record year in 2010 and we especially want to recognize our recall team for successfully managing the large spike in volumes we experienced on a few major recalls. Now, I'll turn it over to Mark.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich. I'd now like to provide insight on our current outlook for 2011. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements. During the fourth quarter, we completed 17 acquisitions, six domestic and 11 international. The incremental reven
componenttext: Thanks, Rich. I'd now like to provide insight on our current outlook for 2011. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements. During the fourth quarter, we completed 17 acquisitions, six domestic and 11 international. The incremental revenue impact in the fourth quarter of 2010 from these acquisitions was $8.8 million. The annualized revenue of these acquisitions is approximately $65 million. Now, keep in mind, our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures and transactional expenses related to acquisitions. Now, I'll provide you the outlook for 2011. We believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $2.76 to $2.80 per share, which we're comfortable with. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2011 will be in the range of $1.55 billion to $1.58 billion, depending on assumptions for growth in foreign exchange. We believe analysts will have an adjusted estimate for free cash flow between $278 million and $283 million and as reported free cash flow of $255 million to $260 million after taking into account the $23 million cash outflow for the recall product reimbursement. CapEx is anticipated between $45 million and $55 million. In closing, we're very excited about the tremendous growth opportunities in 2011 and beyond. We thank you for your time and operator, we'll now go to the question-and-answer section.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Jonathan Ellis from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The first question, on the returns and recall business, can you give us some sense if any of that revenue from existing projects will have an impact, a material impact in the first quarter of 2011? And then can you also update us on your guidance for the
componenttext: The first question, on the returns and recall business, can you give us some sense if any of that revenue from existing projects will have an impact, a material impact in the first quarter of 2011? And then can you also update us on your guidance for the Returns Management business in 2011? Is it still $75 million to $90 million of revenue?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we had one acquisition in that space. So the guidance now for that is $80 million to $100 million. And any overage from Q4 is really not that material. It happens every quarter a little bit but it remains a very uneven business but our guidance fo
componenttext: Yes. So we had one acquisition in that space. So the guidance now for that is $80 million to $100 million. And any overage from Q4 is really not that material. It happens every quarter a little bit but it remains a very uneven business but our guidance for the year is $80 million to $100 million.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And can you talk a little bit about the acquisitions that you made, six domestic, 11 international? I guess I would ask can you break down that in terms of types of acquisitions, med waste versus other services and then also geographic, which countries th
componenttext: And can you talk a little bit about the acquisitions that you made, six domestic, 11 international? I guess I would ask can you break down that in terms of types of acquisitions, med waste versus other services and then also geographic, which countries those acquisitions were in?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, on geographies, out of the 11 international, there were five in the U.K., two in Mexico, two in Brazil, one in Argentina and one in Romania. Of the total quantity of 17, 16 were regulated waste and compliance services businesses and one was a retur
componenttext: First, on geographies, out of the 11 international, there were five in the U.K., two in Mexico, two in Brazil, one in Argentina and one in Romania. Of the total quantity of 17, 16 were regulated waste and compliance services businesses and one was a returns management business, recall management.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question I want to ask about is just on the multiple service offerings for LQ and SQ and I want to make sure I understand correctly sort of the framework here. Should we be working under the assumption that all LQ accounts represent the addressab
componenttext: The next question I want to ask about is just on the multiple service offerings for LQ and SQ and I want to make sure I understand correctly sort of the framework here. Should we be working under the assumption that all LQ accounts represent the addressable market right now for multiple services or is there some segment of LQ customers that are not eligible because they're based abroad or because of their profile?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you can assume that the multiple services that we offer are for the most part applicable to all the geographies. It may not be applicable to every single customer in every geography. I mean but for the most part, what we have on the table now are
componenttext: I think you can assume that the multiple services that we offer are for the most part applicable to all the geographies. It may not be applicable to every single customer in every geography. I mean but for the most part, what we have on the table now are things that benefit customers no matter what regulatory environment they're in.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And would that same principle apply to the SQ customer base that we should assume 100% of SQ customers in most part are eligible for multiple services?
componenttext: And would that same principle apply to the SQ customer base that we should assume 100% of SQ customers in most part are eligible for multiple services?

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Any update on some of the specifically Steri-Safe and Viasystems that you talked about in the past in terms of the rollout outside of the United States? I think you had been rolling out commercially in Canada but any update on either Europe or potentially any progression in South America?

componenttextpreview: Yes. There's a continuation of the rollout in the U.K., Canada and Ireland and the next area that will get focus is Latin America.
componenttext: Yes. There's a continuation of the rollout in the U.K., Canada and Ireland and the next area that will get focus is Latin America.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to just ask about the domestic business for a moment. If we look at some of your customers, I know specifically there have been some pilot projects ongoing with HCA related to different types of service offerings or contract structures. C
componenttext: I guess I wanted to just ask about the domestic business for a moment. If we look at some of your customers, I know specifically there have been some pilot projects ongoing with HCA related to different types of service offerings or contract structures. Can you provide us any update on where your relationship stands with HCA after the pilot projects have been completed now? And then also, any other major customers or hospital that works where these types of projects are ongoing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Normally, it's not in our practice to comment specifically on individual customers. I think since HCA has been a topic, I think you talked about Jonathan, we'll go ahead and tell you that where it stands right now is that following the pilot project that
componenttext: Normally, it's not in our practice to comment specifically on individual customers. I think since HCA has been a topic, I think you talked about Jonathan, we'll go ahead and tell you that where it stands right now is that following the pilot project that we're involved in, HCA decided because they are one of the larger health systems in the United States, to take their 15 divisions, there are multiple hospitals in each division, they decided to take them to market for a total waste stream management service. We're very pleased with the outcome because we obviously bid on the work. We were awarded over 70% of the work at the end. It basically doubled our revenues with HCA. So we're pleased with the outcome and I think from our standpoint, it validates that for this particular type of customer, our multiple service offerings model works.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And are there any specifically at this point but are there hospitals, major customers that are also looking at possible pilot projects along the same lines?
componenttext: And are there any specifically at this point but are there hospitals, major customers that are also looking at possible pilot projects along the same lines?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: As I said, I really don't like to generally comment about what customers are doing for confidentiality reasons.
componenttext: As I said, I really don't like to generally comment about what customers are doing for confidentiality reasons.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ryan Daniels from William Blair and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ryan Daniels from William Blair and Company.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Was hoping just for a quick additional commentary if you could on the impact to the cash flow from the recall business, the $23 million. Is that a pre-payment for services, number one, or is that cash that you'll use to buy product off the shelf or any co
componenttext: Was hoping just for a quick additional commentary if you could on the impact to the cash flow from the recall business, the $23 million. Is that a pre-payment for services, number one, or is that cash that you'll use to buy product off the shelf or any color there and what that is would be helpful.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. We will at times get cash from a party that we do a recall for that is used in absence to reimburse their customers for product that has been returned to us. So we, in essence, due to service. This is a service we provide. But since it's not officiall
componenttext: No. We will at times get cash from a party that we do a recall for that is used in absence to reimburse their customers for product that has been returned to us. So we, in essence, due to service. This is a service we provide. But since it's not officially restricted cash in an accounting term, it has unfortunately been reported in our cash balance. And so it shows up as a positive cash inflow. That's why we highlighted it. But it's not our cash. It's cash we manage on behalf of our customer and that goes straight to their customers when products are returned.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: A great quarter on the M&A front, particularly internationally. If you look at 2011, have you maybe pulled forward some of the business at least domestically? Because some of the tax law changes potentially we do not take place or do you still feel that t
componenttext: A great quarter on the M&A front, particularly internationally. If you look at 2011, have you maybe pulled forward some of the business at least domestically? Because some of the tax law changes potentially we do not take place or do you still feel that the pipeline is as strong as it was even post such a good Q4?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's no doubt that especially in the U.S., obviously, the tax law that was anticipated to change with respect to capital gains stimulated people to do deals and close them before year end. At the end, it didn't change, it really didn't mak
componenttext: Yes, I think there's no doubt that especially in the U.S., obviously, the tax law that was anticipated to change with respect to capital gains stimulated people to do deals and close them before year end. At the end, it didn't change, it really didn't make a difference for most of them. But I think it did stimulate some influx in that and it gave us a good platform. But it will continue. It's $100 million worldwide that's still in the pipeline despite having done those deals so we see good activity both domestically and internationally in multiple geographies. It continues to be good.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I know you're not going to break out new client adds because that's not particularly relevant anymore but I was hoping maybe for some color commentary just on the waste compliance. I know that's kind of the newest incremental service offering you're a
componenttext: And I know you're not going to break out new client adds because that's not particularly relevant anymore but I was hoping maybe for some color commentary just on the waste compliance. I know that's kind of the newest incremental service offering you're adding and I'm curious how that's been received since you've rolled that out over the last year or so across the U.S.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think overall, the traction is very good. We said early on, we were not going to give detail on quantity or things like that but at least, the $200 million opportunity potentially is one that we can move into other geographies and expect to do so. So we
componenttext: I think overall, the traction is very good. We said early on, we were not going to give detail on quantity or things like that but at least, the $200 million opportunity potentially is one that we can move into other geographies and expect to do so. So we're very pleased with it. It's been a good service offering to kind of add to our portfolio.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: In regards to the end market obviously, hospitals facing a little bit more pressure as discussion of Medicaid rate cuts and some of the budgets and I'm curious on the pricing front if you're seeing any more hesitation at all with those customers on pricin
componenttext: In regards to the end market obviously, hospitals facing a little bit more pressure as discussion of Medicaid rate cuts and some of the budgets and I'm curious on the pricing front if you're seeing any more hesitation at all with those customers on pricing or they're being a little more cautious on some of the ancillary compliance offerings or if that's not been very impactful for you thus far?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think because we have multiple service offerings and they help the hospital basically save money, become more efficient, outsource labor and stay compliant and all that, we have not seen any pushback. In fact, I think our growth rates reflect that hospi
componenttext: I think because we have multiple service offerings and they help the hospital basically save money, become more efficient, outsource labor and stay compliant and all that, we have not seen any pushback. In fact, I think our growth rates reflect that hospitals continue to look at our services as something that makes economic and an overall sense for them.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the final one, you mentioned the HCA contract that's going to double your revenue. Was that reflected in the quarter? Did you see those new contract awards come into play or is that going to be in 2011 when we'll see the uptick there?
componenttext: And the final one, you mentioned the HCA contract that's going to double your revenue. Was that reflected in the quarter? Did you see those new contract awards come into play or is that going to be in 2011 when we'll see the uptick there?

componenttextpreview: I was wondering in terms of the guidance that you're offering here, I assume it excludes any kind of restructuring expenses. But could you tell us if it includes or excludes the transactional acquisition expenses? And then, the acquisition integration exp
componenttext: I was wondering in terms of the guidance that you're offering here, I assume it excludes any kind of restructuring expenses. But could you tell us if it includes or excludes the transactional acquisition expenses? And then, the acquisition integration expenses, could you address both of those separately?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It does include the integration expenses but does not include the transactional expenses that are listed separately on our press release.
componenttext: It does include the integration expenses but does not include the transactional expenses that are listed separately on our press release.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The way that's being running here in the past year is somewhere between $500,000 and $1 million seems to be the range?
componenttext: The way that's being running here in the past year is somewhere between $500,000 and $1 million seems to be the range?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it really depends very heavily on deal flow. We obviously have some expenses still on pending transactions that are continuing. So I mean it'll continue because we are acquisitive and the pipeline is robust.
componenttext: Yes, it really depends very heavily on deal flow. We obviously have some expenses still on pending transactions that are continuing. So I mean it'll continue because we are acquisitive and the pipeline is robust.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then as you look out here, I'm just wondering about the growth rate longer term. What do you see as the most important growth drivers over the next three to five years? Could you talk about growth initiatives that you're focused on now that are both b
componenttext: And then as you look out here, I'm just wondering about the growth rate longer term. What do you see as the most important growth drivers over the next three to five years? Could you talk about growth initiatives that you're focused on now that are both big enough and growth enough to move the needle for Stericycle going forward? Which are the ones that you're looking and saying these are the very promising ones?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think just kind of trying to address that, I think that for us, it's the multiple services. Remember, we're looking at this year 8% to 10% in SQ and 5% to 8% growth in LQ. Good strong organic growth blended for both international and domestic. But as I
componenttext: I think just kind of trying to address that, I think that for us, it's the multiple services. Remember, we're looking at this year 8% to 10% in SQ and 5% to 8% growth in LQ. Good strong organic growth blended for both international and domestic. But as I said in my prepared comments, what we're really looking at is an expanding portfolio of services, and for example, we mentioned Rx Waste, which domestically is a $200 million plus opportunity for us. That has really just begun to barely touch our customer base. And as I mentioned in my comments, it's somewhere between 20% or only a third of our customers depending LQ, SQ have even adopted more than one of our service offerings. So I think that's going to be a large part of the growth drivers. And then we'll continue to do our acquisitions because as Frank, said we're an acquisitive company. So the combination of the two should really fuel the growth going forward.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Finally, in terms of the international contribution to your growth, could you talk about the markets that you're in now as you look at those, which of those are the most promising? It looks like you're making some moves here in Brazil and South America. C
componenttext: Finally, in terms of the international contribution to your growth, could you talk about the markets that you're in now as you look at those, which of those are the most promising? It looks like you're making some moves here in Brazil and South America. Could you talk about the markets that you see as the brightest?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think of the international markets, the markets that we're in, we continue to focus our strategy of continuing to build leadership position in each of those. So as you notice, the ones we were doing were expansion geography within the country or tuck in
componenttext: I think of the international markets, the markets that we're in, we continue to focus our strategy of continuing to build leadership position in each of those. So as you notice, the ones we were doing were expansion geography within the country or tuck ins within the country. So we'll continue to do those place. There's other countries that we're looking at that we won't make an entry until we see the right combination. But I think the key is get the right kind of platform, look at the consolidation opportunities, stabilize and integrate that business and post that, bring the know-how and systems to expand services into those countries. And then also vice versa. We pick up ideas and learn from their organizations as well on things we can bring back to the domestic market.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine from JPMorgan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you give us the debt leverage calculation based on your covenant for the quarter and remind us what you project that to be upon closing of the HWS acquisition?
componenttext: Can you give us the debt leverage calculation based on your covenant for the quarter and remind us what you project that to be upon closing of the HWS acquisition?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the debt at the end was 2.15. That compared to 2.16 at the end of the third quarter and 2.51 at the end of fourth quarter of last year. It's at the low end of our range. Our range that we're very comfortable with is between two and three. I think if th
componenttext: So the debt at the end was 2.15. That compared to 2.16 at the end of the third quarter and 2.51 at the end of fourth quarter of last year. It's at the low end of our range. Our range that we're very comfortable with is between two and three. I think if the consumption is done off the transaction with HWS, that could go in between 2.5, 2.3, depending on all their acquisitions and activities.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on the returns, there's obviously a huge few quarters here and it seems like most or all the upside is really from recalls but if we look at your guidance for '11 relative to what your initial guidance was for '10, it doesn't really project much
componenttext: And then on the returns, there's obviously a huge few quarters here and it seems like most or all the upside is really from recalls but if we look at your guidance for '11 relative to what your initial guidance was for '10, it doesn't really project much underlying growth, I guess, in returns if you x out the recall. So I guess I would ask if you focus on the return side of that business, are you seeing growth? Are you seeing increasing adoption rates or penetration rates? And what thoughts should we have regarding the secular growth potential of the returns business over a three to five-year horizon?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the returns business overall is obviously a slower growth than it has been like the recalls for us. The recalls remained very uneven but when it does come with larger recalls, it does fall very nicely to the bottom line. So that gives us obviously
componenttext: I think the returns business overall is obviously a slower growth than it has been like the recalls for us. The recalls remained very uneven but when it does come with larger recalls, it does fall very nicely to the bottom line. So that gives us obviously a great cash inflow into the business that we can then use in that business and elsewhere.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Lastly, we're now following the debate regarding the healthcare legislation. Have you seen any impact in your business or do you anticipate any impact in your business associated with the way the legislative process plays out or is this really a non-event
componenttext: Lastly, we're now following the debate regarding the healthcare legislation. Have you seen any impact in your business or do you anticipate any impact in your business associated with the way the legislative process plays out or is this really a non-event in your opinion?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think overall as we've said before, the healthcare reform should increase volume with our small customers. We do see it overall as a positive to our business. It moves volumes potentially a little bit from hospitals to the Small Quantity Generators. So
componenttext: I think overall as we've said before, the healthcare reform should increase volume with our small customers. We do see it overall as a positive to our business. It moves volumes potentially a little bit from hospitals to the Small Quantity Generators. So we don't think it will be a negative.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Lastly, the tax rate came in a little bit higher, Frank than we were projecting. Is this quarter's rate a good go forward rate for 2011?
componenttext: Lastly, the tax rate came in a little bit higher, Frank than we were projecting. Is this quarter's rate a good go forward rate for 2011?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. The thing is when you have larger transaction expenses, many of those could relate to a stock deal and an acquisition. Those are not FX deductible. On the kind of an operational level, without those transactional expenses, the tax rate was about 37%.
componenttext: No. The thing is when you have larger transaction expenses, many of those could relate to a stock deal and an acquisition. Those are not FX deductible. On the kind of an operational level, without those transactional expenses, the tax rate was about 37%.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sorry for beating up this recall issue but can you talk maybe a little bit about the overall market, what's happened in the last year or so? I know it seems the FDA would be more active but are these overall recalls larger in size where companies don't ha
componenttext: Sorry for beating up this recall issue but can you talk maybe a little bit about the overall market, what's happened in the last year or so? I know it seems the FDA would be more active but are these overall recalls larger in size where companies don't have the in-house resources and you're helping them out? Or is the FDA going after smaller companies that don't have any experience? What's the overall trends that you're able to take advantage of it here?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the overall trend here is that the FDA definitely has tightened up and even now, the latest step with the full modernization act kind of expands the powers of the FDA and gives them the right to recall certain products. So the FDA definitely has m
componenttext: I think the overall trend here is that the FDA definitely has tightened up and even now, the latest step with the full modernization act kind of expands the powers of the FDA and gives them the right to recall certain products. So the FDA definitely has more powers now than it did before and it's enforcing more. It will remain an uneven business for us. It has been a great year. There have been larger recalls. The quantity of recalls again and the awareness campaign continues to work in that we do more recalls and also in more industries. And that's continuously also with the acquisition that we did that expands the capabilities. So we are allocating resources there and foresee that that comes. But at the same time, in giving guidance, we really don't know what the amount of recalls are going to be in the year. And we've had that happen to us in '09 where we were probably getting ahead of us a little bit in the guidance and then there were no large recalls in that year. And then if there are, great. Then everyone will see the positive. But if there aren't, then we haven't overextended ourselves in the guidance.

componenttext: I think our trend in general has been that our price is in line with what it has been in the past. componenttext: No. Obviously, the absolute number, you're mixing up two things. You're mixing growth with absolute in the quarter. Obviously, there was returns in the recall business in '09. So I can take you through those numbers separately but that's not the correct count. The internal growth, if you look at it excluding all the factors for just as we said in our scripted part for the business, for the SQ, the domestic business was about 8% internal growth. And then the international internal growth was about 8%. And then we normally don't do the recalls and returns business in the growth number because it is so swinging. In fact, that one was 161% growth factor if you look at it from a percentage point of view. But we think it's not totally the right way to project that. So in absolute terms, that was a business that did $42.6 million in revenues and in the prior year, that was $16.1 million.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Jessica, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Laura Murphy, Vice President of Corporate Fi
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Jessica, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Laura Murphy, Vice President of Corporate Finance, you may begin.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's quarterly conference call. Joining me on today's call will be Frank ten Brink, CFO; Rich Kogler, COO; and Mark Miller, Chairman and CEO. I will now read the safe harbor statement. Statements by Stericycle in this conference call
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's quarterly conference call. Joining me on today's call will be Frank ten Brink, CFO; Rich Kogler, COO; and Mark Miller, Chairman and CEO. 
I will now read the safe harbor statement. Statements by Stericycle in this conference call that are not strictly historical are forward looking. Forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks and should be viewed with caution. Factors described in the company's Form 10-K, 10-Qs, as well as its other filings with the SEC could affect the company's actual results and could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from expected results. The company makes no commitment to disclose any revisions to forward-looking statements or any facts, events or circumstances after the statement may bear upon forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn it over to Frank.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows: revenues were $393.5 million, up 25.5% from $313.5 million in the fourth quarter of '09; Domestic revenues were $292.6 million; Domestic Regulated Waste and Compliance Services revenues
componenttext:
Thank you, Laura. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows: revenues were $393.5 million, up 25.5% from $313.5 million in the fourth quarter of '09; Domestic revenues were $292.6 million; Domestic Regulated Waste and Compliance Services revenues were $250 million; and the Returns and Recall revenues were $42.6 million. The International revenues were $100.9 million, including an unfavorable exchange impact of $1 million; domestic internal growth, excluding Returns Management, was up approximately 8%, consisting of Small Quantity, up 9% and Large Quantity, up 6%; international internal growth, adjusted for exchange, was up approximately 8%; acquisitions less than 12 months old contributed $32.5 million to the growth in the quarter; gross profit was $182.5 million or 46.4% of revenues; and SG&A expense was $75.7 million or 19.2% of revenues. 
Net interest expense was $10.7 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $50 million or $0.50 per share on an as-reported basis and $0.69 adjusted for after-tax transaction expenses related also other adjustments. At the end of the quarter, our revolver borrowings were approximately $175 million and is floating at LIBOR plus 75 basis points. The unused portion of the revolver debt at the end of the quarter was approximately $491 million. 
As we mentioned before, in October 15, 2010, we received the $400 million private placement, and those proceeds were used to prepay part of the term debt that we have and reduce the revolver. We purchased 709,867 shares of common stock in the open market in the quarter in an amount of $50.7 million. Capital spending was $12.4 million, and the DSO at the end of the quarter was 51 days. The cash provided from operations was $325.7 million for the year, which includes $23 million of cash received in the fourth quarter from our customers to be used for recalled product reimbursement. 
Those are my comments. I will now turn it over to Rich.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Frank. At the end of the quarter, we had approximately 485,400 accounts of which over 472,000 were small and the remainder were large. We continue to see strong growth worldwide, driven by new account acquisition and the adoption of our expanding
componenttext:
Thanks, Frank. At the end of the quarter, we had approximately 485,400 accounts of which over 472,000 were small and the remainder were large. We continue to see strong growth worldwide, driven by new account acquisition and the adoption of our expanding portfolio of service offerings. With our Large Quantity customers, we have multiple service offerings, which add to the value of each account. And today, less than 20% of our LQ customers are using our multiple services, leaving more than 80% of our LQ customer base available for growth. Likewise, with our Small Quantity customers, we offer multiple services that increase the value of an account. And today, approximately 1/3 of our SQ customers utilize multiple services, leaving 2/3 of our customer base available for growth. 
In closing, we want to thank each member of our worldwide team for their solid performance that lead to a record year in 2010, and we especially want to recognize our recall team for successfully managing the large spike in volume we experienced on a few major recalls. 
Now, I'll turn it over to Mark.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich. I'd now like to provide insight on our current outlook for 2011. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements. During the fourth quarter, we completed 17 acquisitions, six domestic and 11 international. The incremental rev
componenttext:
Thanks, Rich. I'd now like to provide insight on our current outlook for 2011. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements. 
During the fourth quarter, we completed 17 acquisitions, six domestic and 11 international. The incremental revenue impact in the fourth quarter of 2010 from these acquisitions was $8.8 million. The annualized revenue of these acquisitions is approximately $65 million. Now keep in mind, our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures and transactional expenses related to acquisitions. 
Now to provide you the outlook for 2011. We believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $2.76 to $2.80 per share which we are comfortable with. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2011 will be in the range of $1.55 billion to $1.58 billion, depending on assumptions for growth in foreign exchange. We believe analysts will have an adjusted estimate for free cash flow between $278 million and $283 million, and as reported free cash flow of $255 million to $260 million after taking into account the $23 million cash outflow for the recall product reimbursement. CapEx is anticipated between $45 million and $55 million. 
In closing, we're very excited about the tremendous growth opportunities in 2011 and beyond. We thank you for your time and operator, we'll now go into the question-and-answer section.

It happens every quarter a little bit, but it remains a very uneven business but our guidance for the year is $80 million to $100 million.

componenttext: And can you talk a little bit about the acquisitions that you made, six domestic, 11 international? I guess I would ask, can you break down that in terms of types of acquisitions, med waste versus other services and then also geographic, which countries those acquisitions were in?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, on geographies. Out of the 11 international, there were five in the U.K., two in Mexico, two in Brazil, one in Argentina and one in Romania. Of the total quantity of 17, 16 were regulated waste and compliance services businesses and one was a retur
componenttext: First, on geographies. Out of the 11 international, there were five in the U.K., two in Mexico, two in Brazil, one in Argentina and one in Romania. Of the total quantity of 17, 16 were regulated waste and compliance services businesses and one was a returns management business, recall management.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question I want to ask about is just on the multiple service offerings for LQ and SQ, and I want to make sure I understand correctly sort of the framework here. Should we be working under the assumption that all LQ accounts represent the addressa
componenttext: The next question I want to ask about is just on the multiple service offerings for LQ and SQ, and I want to make sure I understand correctly sort of the framework here. Should we be working under the assumption that all LQ accounts represent the addressable market right now for multiple services or is there some segment of LQ customers that are not eligible because they're based abroad or because of their profile?

componenttext: I think you can assume that the multiple services that we offer are, for the most, part applicable to all the geographies. It may not be applicable to every single customer in every geography. I mean but for the most part, what we have on the table now are things that benefit customers no matter what regulatory environment they're in.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Any update on some of the specifically Steri-Safe and Bio Systems. I know you've talked about in the past in terms of the rollout outside of the United States? I think you have been rolling out commercially in Canada, but any update on either Europe or potentially any progression in South America?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's a continuation of the rollout in the U.K., Canada and Ireland and the next area that will get focus is Latin America.
componenttext: Yes. There's a continuation of the rollout in the U.K., Canada and Ireland and the next area that will get focus is Latin America.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to just ask about the domestic business for a moment. If we'd look at some of your customers, I know specifically there have been some pilot projects ongoing with HCA related to different types of service offerings or contract structures.
componenttext: I guess I wanted to just ask about the domestic business for a moment. If we'd look at some of your customers, I know specifically there have been some pilot projects ongoing with HCA related to different types of service offerings or contract structures. Can you provide us any update on where your relationship stands with HCA after the pilot projects have been completed now? And then also, any other major customers or hospital that works where these same types of projects are ongoing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Normally, it's not in our practice to comment specifically on individual customers. I think since HCA has been a topic, I think you talked about, Jonathan, we'll go ahead and tell you that where it stands right now is that following the pilot project that
componenttext: Normally, it's not in our practice to comment specifically on individual customers. I think since HCA has been a topic, I think you talked about, Jonathan, we'll go ahead and tell you that where it stands right now is that following the pilot project that we're involved in, HCA decided because they are one of the larger health systems in the United States, to take their 15 divisions -- there are multiple hospitals of each division, they decide to take them to market for a total waste stream management service. We're very pleased with the outcome, because we obviously bid on the work. We were awarded over 70% of the work at the end. It basically doubled our revenues with HCA. So we're pleased with the outcome and I think from our standpoint, it validates that for this particular type of customer, our multiple service offerings model works.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are there other hospitals, major customers that are also looking at possible pilot projects along the same lines?
componenttext: Are there other hospitals, major customers that are also looking at possible pilot projects along the same lines?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: As I said, I really don't like to generally comment about what customers are doing for confidentiality reasons.
componenttext: As I said, I really don't like to generally comment about what customers are doing for confidentiality reasons.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ryan Daniels from William Blair & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ryan Daniels from William Blair & Company.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Was hoping just for a quick additional commentary, if you could, on the impact to the cash flows from the Recall business, the $23 million. Is that a pre payment for services, number one, or is that cash that you'll use to actually go buy product off the
componenttext: Was hoping just for a quick additional commentary, if you could, on the impact to the cash flows from the Recall business, the $23 million. Is that a pre payment for services, number one, or is that cash that you'll use to actually go buy product off the shelf? Or any color there and what that is would be helpful.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. We will at times get cash from a party that we do a recall for that is used in absence to reimburse their customers for a product that has been returned to us. So we, in essence, due to service, this is a service we provide. But since it's not officia
componenttext: No. We will at times get cash from a party that we do a recall for that is used in absence to reimburse their customers for a product that has been returned to us. So we, in essence, due to service, this is a service we provide. But since it's not officially restricted cash in an accounting term, it has unfortunately be reported in our cash balance. And so it shows up as a positive cash inflow. That's why we highlighted it. But we don't see that as not our cash. It's cash that we manage on behalf of our customer, and that goes straight to their customers when products are returned.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: A great quarter on the M&A front, particularly internationally. If you look at 2011, have you guys maybe pulled forward some of the business, at least domestically? Because in some of the tax law changes that were potentially but did not take place? Or do
componenttext: A great quarter on the M&A front, particularly internationally. If you look at 2011, have you guys maybe pulled forward some of the business, at least domestically? Because in some of the tax law changes that were potentially but did not take place? Or do you still feel that the pipeline is as kind of as strong as it was even post such a good Q4?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's no doubt that especially in the U.S., obviously, the tax law that was anticipated to change with respect to capital gains stimulated people to do deals and close them before year end. Now at the end, it didn't change, so it really did
componenttext: Yes, I think there's no doubt that especially in the U.S., obviously, the tax law that was anticipated to change with respect to capital gains stimulated people to do deals and close them before year end. Now at the end, it didn't change, so it really didn't make a difference for most of them. But I think it did stimulate some influx in that, and it gave us a good platform but it will continue. I mean it's $100 million worldwide still in the pipeline despite having done those deals, so we see good activity both domestically and internationally in multiple geographies. It continues to be good.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I know you guys aren't going to break out new client adds because that's not particularly relevant anymore, but I was hoping maybe for some color commentary just on the Rx Waste compliance. I know that's kind of the newest incremental service offering
componenttext: And I know you guys aren't going to break out new client adds because that's not particularly relevant anymore, but I was hoping maybe for some color commentary just on the Rx Waste compliance. I know that's kind of the newest incremental service offering you're adding, and I'm curious how that's been received kind of as you rolled that out over the last year or so across the U.S.?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think overall, the traction is very good. We said early on, we were not going to give detail on quantity or things like that. But it's at least a $200 million opportunity and potentially is one that we can move into other geographies and expect to do so
componenttext: I think overall, the traction is very good. We said early on, we were not going to give detail on quantity or things like that. But it's at least a $200 million opportunity and potentially is one that we can move into other geographies and expect to do so. So we're very pleased with it. It's been a good service offering to kind of add to our portfolio.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: In regards to the end market, obviously, hospitals facing a little bit more pressure as discussion of Medicaid rate cuts and some of the budgets and I'm curious on the pricing front if you're seeing any more hesitation at all with those customers on prici
componenttext: In regards to the end market, obviously, hospitals facing a little bit more pressure as discussion of Medicaid rate cuts and some of the budgets and I'm curious on the pricing front if you're seeing any more hesitation at all with those customers on pricing or they're being a little more cautious on some of the ancillary compliance offerings or if that's not been very impactful for you guys thus far?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think because we have multiple service offerings and they help the hospital basically save money, become more efficient, outsource labor and stay compliant and all of that. We have not seen any pushback. In fact, I think our growth rates reflect that th
componenttext: I think because we have multiple service offerings and they help the hospital basically save money, become more efficient, outsource labor and stay compliant and all of that. We have not seen any pushback. In fact, I think our growth rates reflect that the hospitals continue to look at our services as something that makes economic and an overall sense for them.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the HCA contract that's going to double your revenue. Was that reflected in the quarter? Did you see those new contract awards come into play or is that going to be in 2011 when we'll kind of see the uptick there?
componenttext: You mentioned the HCA contract that's going to double your revenue. Was that reflected in the quarter? Did you see those new contract awards come into play or is that going to be in 2011 when we'll kind of see the uptick there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering in terms of the guidance that you're offering here, I assume it excludes any kind of restructuring expenses. But could you tell us if it includes or excludes the transactional acquisition expenses? And then the acquisition integration expe
componenttext: I was wondering in terms of the guidance that you're offering here, I assume it excludes any kind of restructuring expenses. But could you tell us if it includes or excludes the transactional acquisition expenses? And then the acquisition integration expenses, could you address both of those separately?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It does include the integration expenses but does not include the transactional expenses that are listed separately on our press release.
componenttext: It does include the integration expenses but does not include the transactional expenses that are listed separately on our press release.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the way that's been running here in the past year is somewhere between $500,000 and $1 million seems to be the range?
componenttext: And the way that's been running here in the past year is somewhere between $500,000 and $1 million seems to be the range?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it really depends very heavily on deal flow. We obviously have some expenses still on pending transactions that are continuing. So I mean it'll continue because we are acquisitive and then the pipeline is robust.
componenttext: Yes, it really depends very heavily on deal flow. We obviously have some expenses still on pending transactions that are continuing. So I mean it'll continue because we are acquisitive and then the pipeline is robust.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then as you look out here, I'm just wondering about the growth rate longer term. What do you see as the most important growth drivers over the next three to five years? Could you talk about growth initiatives that you're focused on now that are both b
componenttext: And then as you look out here, I'm just wondering about the growth rate longer term. What do you see as the most important growth drivers over the next three to five years? Could you talk about growth initiatives that you're focused on now that are both big enough and growth enough to move the needle for Stericycle going forward? Which are the ones that you're looking at and saying these are the very promising ones?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think just kind of trying to address that, I think that for us, it's the multiple services. Remember, we're looking at this year 8% to 10% in SQ and 5% to 8% growth in LQ. Good strong organic growth blended for both international and domestic. But
componenttext: Well, I think just kind of trying to address that, I think that for us, it's the multiple services. Remember, we're looking at this year 8% to 10% in SQ and 5% to 8% growth in LQ. Good strong organic growth blended for both international and domestic. But as I said in my prepared comments, what we're really looking at is an expanding portfolio of services. And for example, we mentioned Rx Waste, which domestically is a $200 million plus opportunity for us, that has really just begun to barely touch our customer base. And as I mentioned in my comments, I mean it's somewhere between 20% or only a third of our customers depending LQ, SQ have even adopted more than one of our service offerings. So I think that's going to be a large part of the growth drivers. And then we'll continue to do our acquisitions because as Frank, said we're an acquisitive company. So the combination of the two should really fuel the growth going forward.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then finally, in terms of the international contribution to your growth, could you talk about the markets that you're in now as you look at those, which of those are the most promising? It looks like you're making some moves here in Brazil and South A
componenttext: And then finally, in terms of the international contribution to your growth, could you talk about the markets that you're in now as you look at those, which of those are the most promising? It looks like you're making some moves here in Brazil and South America. Could you talk about the markets that you see as the brightest?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think of the international markets, the markets that we're in, we continue to focus our strategy of continuing to build leadership position in each of those. So as you notice, the ones we were doing were expansion geography within the country or tuck in
componenttext: I think of the international markets, the markets that we're in, we continue to focus our strategy of continuing to build leadership position in each of those. So as you notice, the ones we were doing were expansion geography within the country or tuck ins within the country. So we'll continue to do those place. There's other countries that we're looking at that we'll make an entry until we see the right combination. But I think the key is get the right kind of platform, look at the consolidation opportunities, stabilize and integrate that business and then post that, bring the know how and systems to expand services into those countries. And then also vice versa. We pick up ideas and learn from their organizations as well of things that we can bring back to the domestic market.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine from JPMorgan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you give us the debt leverage calculation based on your covenant for the quarter and remind us what you project that to be upon closing of the HWS acquisition?
componenttext: Can you give us the debt leverage calculation based on your covenant for the quarter and remind us what you project that to be upon closing of the HWS acquisition?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the debt at the end was 2.15. That compared to 2.16 at the end of the third quarter and 2.51 at the end of fourth quarter of last year. It's at the low end of our range. Our range that we're very comfortable with is between two and three. I think if th
componenttext: So the debt at the end was 2.15. That compared to 2.16 at the end of the third quarter and 2.51 at the end of fourth quarter of last year. It's at the low end of our range. Our range that we're very comfortable with is between two and three. I think if the consumption is done off the transaction with HWS, that could go in between 2.5, 2.3, depending on all their acquisitions and activities.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on the returns, there's obviously a huge few quarters here and it seems like most or all the upside is really from Recalls, but if we look at your guidance for '11 relative to what your initial guidance was for '10, it doesn't really project much
componenttext: And then on the returns, there's obviously a huge few quarters here and it seems like most or all the upside is really from Recalls, but if we look at your guidance for '11 relative to what your initial guidance was for '10, it doesn't really project much underlying growth, I guess, in returns if you x out the recall. So I guess I would ask if you focus on the return side of that business, are you seeing growth? Are you seeing increasing adoption rates or penetration rates? And what thoughts should we have regarding the secular growth potential of the returns business over a three to five-year horizon?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the Returns business overall is obviously a slower growth than it has been like the Recalls for us. The Recalls remain very uneven but when it does come with larger recalls, it does fall very nicely to the bottom line. And so that gives us obvious
componenttext: I think the Returns business overall is obviously a slower growth than it has been like the Recalls for us. The Recalls remain very uneven but when it does come with larger recalls, it does fall very nicely to the bottom line. And so that gives us obviously a great cash inflow into the business that we can then use in that business and elsewhere.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And maybe lastly, we're now following the debate regarding the healthcare legislation. Have you seen any impact in your business or do you anticipate any impact in your business associated with the way the legislative process plays out or is this really a
componenttext: And maybe lastly, we're now following the debate regarding the healthcare legislation. Have you seen any impact in your business or do you anticipate any impact in your business associated with the way the legislative process plays out or is this really a non-event in your opinion?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think overall as we've said before, the healthcare reform should increase volume with our small customers. We do see it overall as a positive to our business. It moves volumes potentially a little bit from hospitals to the Small Quantity Generators. So
componenttext: I think overall as we've said before, the healthcare reform should increase volume with our small customers. We do see it overall as a positive to our business. It moves volumes potentially a little bit from hospitals to the Small Quantity Generators. So we don't think it will be a negative.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The tax rate came in a little bit higher, Frank, than we were projecting. Is this quarter's rate a good go-forward rate for 2011?
componenttext: The tax rate came in a little bit higher, Frank, than we were projecting. Is this quarter's rate a good go-forward rate for 2011?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. The thing is when you have larger transactional expenses, many of those could relate to a stock deal and an acquisition. Those are not FX deductible. On kind of an operational level, without those transactional expenses, the tax rate was about 37%.
componenttext: No. The thing is when you have larger transactional expenses, many of those could relate to a stock deal and an acquisition. Those are not FX deductible. On kind of an operational level, without those transactional expenses, the tax rate was about 37%.

componenttext: It looks like as far as your organizational structure with how you manage international operations, kind of shifted at year end. Could you take us through that a little bit more on how you are looking at your global operations, how you're operating them and how you're approaching M&A?

componenttext: The international business, each country has a country management team and then we also had built up area management teams for managing the Latin America, for managing Europe. And the thought process is really to have as much of the resources close to the customers and the markets as possible and those regional managers then report them to Rich Kogler, the Chief Operating Officer.

componenttext: If you look really at the impact of mix on the business with the far higher returns management with large recalls, that may be had a 30 bp headwind. headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Owczarski from Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Owczarski from Avondale Partners.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sorry for beating up this recall issue, but can you talk maybe a little bit about the overall market, what's happened in the last year or so? I know we've seeing the FDA be more active but are these overall recalls larger in size where companies don't hav
componenttext: Sorry for beating up this recall issue, but can you talk maybe a little bit about the overall market, what's happened in the last year or so? I know we've seeing the FDA be more active but are these overall recalls larger in size where companies don't have the in-house resources and you're helping them out? Or is the FDA going after smaller companies that don't have any experience? What's the overall trends that you're able to take advantage of here?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the overall trend is that the FDA definitely has tightened up and even now, the latest step with the full modernization act, it kind of expands the powers of the FDA and gives them the right to recall certain products. So the FDA definitely has mo
componenttext: I think the overall trend is that the FDA definitely has tightened up and even now, the latest step with the full modernization act, it kind of expands the powers of the FDA and gives them the right to recall certain products. So the FDA definitely has more powers now than it did before, and it's enforcing more. It will remain an uneven business for us. It has been a great year. There have been larger recalls. The quantity of recalls again and the awareness campaign continues to work in that we do more recalls and also in more industries. And that's continuously also with the acquisition that we did that expands the capabilities. So we are allocating resources there and foresee that, that comes. But at the same time, in giving guidance, we really don't know what the amount of recalls are going to be in a year. And we've had that happen to us in '09 where we were probably getting ahead of us a little bit in the guidance and then there were no large recalls in that year. And then if there are, great, then everyone will see the positive. But if there aren't, then we haven't overextended ourselves in the guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then for the Rx Waste program, now that it's fully rolled out, are those kind of the first adopters? Is that mostly targeted towards medical offices or do you target the pharmaceutical manufacturers as well? And what do those pharma manufacturers do r
componenttext: And then for the Rx Waste program, now that it's fully rolled out, are those kind of the first adopters? Is that mostly targeted towards medical offices or do you target the pharmaceutical manufacturers as well? And what do those pharma manufacturers do right now for the waste?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the key here is the hospitals. We do look at in the future at manufacturers and retail because they have to dispose of that too. So we're addressing each market sector over time, but households has been the first focus.
componenttext: So the key here is the hospitals. We do look at in the future at manufacturers and retail because they have to dispose of that too. So we're addressing each market sector over time, but households has been the first focus.

componenttextpreview: I think our trend in general has been that our price is in line with what it has been in the past. I would say that in most of the markets in the past, the most overheated market probably was the U.K. and Ireland, which after the '08 crash, kind of came b
componenttext: I think our trend in general has been that our price is in line with what it has been in the past. I would say that in most of the markets in the past, the most overheated market probably was the U.K. and Ireland, which after the '08 crash, kind of came back to normal. But in most other markets, things have been rational and logical, and that really meant that our multiple has been fairly stable.

componenttext: The way we kind of looked at SG&A and you've seen our guidance is that we'll continue to use the SG&A to feed the hot end. And as we've seen, we're doing a pretty good job of balancing SG&A spend with the growth. I think we're getting the growth rates that we want.

So internal growth, if you look at it excluding all the factors for just as we said in our scripted part for the business, for the SQ out, the domestic business was about 8% internal growth. In fact, that one was 161% growth factor if you look at it from a percentage point of view. But we think it's not totally the right way to project that. So in absolute terms, that was a business that did $42.6 million in revenues and in the prior year, that was $16.1 million.
